objects.name: Ghimob Banking Trojan
objects.description:
# Summary

Ghimob is a new banking Trojan targeting Brazilian financial apps with functionality in place to expand to other regions. Analysis by Kaspersky leads them to believe the campaign is related to Guildma, part of the Tétrade family of banking Trojans.

# Threat Type

- Malware, Banking Trojan

# Overview

Kaspersky has published their analysis of Ghimob, a mobile RAT that appears to be related to the Tétrade family of banking Trojans, specifically the Guilda threat actor. The campaign was discovered on infrastructure tied to the Guildma Windows malware that victims were directed to via a link in a phishing email. Visiting the same website via an Android browser led to the download of a different payload, an APK. After performing anti-debugging checks, the APK leverages accessibility mode to grant the application the access it needs to gain persistence and provide the operators with RAT functionality. C2 connection is established using fallback C2s in a configuration file to identify the real C2 address. Unlike other Brazilian banking Trojans that use overlays to steal credentials from financial apps, Ghimob using accessibility features to read field values of interest directly. While targeting is primarily focused on Brazilian victims, the code indicates financial apps in Paraguay, Peru, Portugal, Germany, Angola and Mozambique are also able to be targeted if the operator chooses to expand into these regions. For more information, see the Securelist blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

See the Reports section to the right for a list of indicators of compromise.

# Recommendations

- Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
- Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
- Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
- Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
- Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.

# Reference

- https://securelist.com/ghimob-tetrade-threat-mobile-devices/99228[/](https://securelist.com/ghimob-tetrade-threat-mobile-devices/99228/)

Ghimob is a new banking Trojan targeting Brazilian financial apps with functionality in place to expand to other regions. Analysis by Kaspersky leads them to believe the campaign is related to Guildma, part of the Tétrade family of banking Trojans.

# Threat Type

- Malware, Banking Trojan

# Overview

Kaspersky has published their analysis of Ghimob, a mobile RAT that appears to be related to the Tétrade family of banking Trojans, specifically the Guilda threat actor. The campaign was discovered on infrastructure tied to the Guildma Windows malware that victims were directed to via a link in a phishing email. Visiting the same website via an Android browser led to the download of a different payload, an APK. After performing anti-debugging checks, the APK leverages accessibility mode to grant the application the access it needs to gain persistence and provide the operators with RAT functionality. C2 connection is established using fallback C2s in a configuration file to identify the real C2 address. Unlike other Brazilian banking Trojans that use overlays to steal credentials from financial apps, Ghimob using accessibility features to read field values of interest directly. While targeting is primarily focused on Brazilian victims, the code indicates financial apps in Paraguay, Peru, Portugal, Germany, Angola and Mozambique are also able to be targeted if the operator chooses to expand into these regions. For more information, see the Securelist blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

See the Reports section to the right for a list of indicators of compromise.

# Recommendations
